recordings.loc: San Dimas Canyon, San Gabriel Mountains, Los Angeles County, California
recordings.rmk:
Uploaded primarily for the grebe, but this might also be considered as a soundscape due to all the other species that were vocalizing at the time of the recording.

Recorded in a deep canyon with a reservoir that has a lot of water.  Numerous migranting passerines were also in the area.   

Equipment: Sony PCM-M10 and a Sennheiser ME67.

Edits: trimmed and normalized to -3 dB.

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.type: call, extra-pair interaction calls, pair interaction calls
recordings.rmk: complicated situation, with apparently two pairs now with territories, dividing up the main cattail bed, and at least four more birds on the rest of the pond, wanting in; so some vocalization are intra-pair, and some competitive with aspiring birds; after 3:18, two pairs vocalizing, perhaps internal; after 3:40, alarm calls from one pair, then calls and song from another pair in the background, with more from two other birds off to the side; after 5:06, two bird vocal interaction; after 5:21, some interaction calls;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: two birds in alternate plumage, swimming up to each and giving pair interaction calls;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: interaction calls between a bird in breeding plumage and one in basic plumage; interval shortened at 0:09, 0:29 (song);

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: pair contact calls at the start and a duet after 0:46, which seemed to be from a different pair;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: interval altered at 0:08; at least three social units on the pond; most of it has been by an unseen pair, including the prior recording at 11:57, in the cattails; the vocalizations after 5:10 are by the second pair, in the cattails also, and the ones after 6:50 are by a third pair out on the pond; those after 7:00 (interval altered) are by the primary/first pair; no grebes from 0:15 to 2:50, after which sharp alarm calls until 5:00 from inside the reeds and sounds of a bird diving (obviously much going on in there!); much ugly rustling by a grackle flock in the cattails;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: two birds in alternate plumage; two warning calls early, pair contact calls after 0:23 when they were out of sight of each other, then more tentative ones when they were in sight, e.g., after 0:42 and 1:20;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: song duet and then pair contact call from a nesting pair;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: warning or alarm calls from a breeding-plumage adult, believed to be the male, that was keeping an eye on me a long way away from the nest;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: four birds swimming energetically, somewhat in a line, some element of chase involved, including a rapid swim (flying across the surface) at 0:23, and then went under the surface; victorious bird returned to its territory, the others remaining in their corner of the pond; alarm calls after 0:13 and 0:21, full excitement after 0:16, many little calls throughout;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: interaction calls within the dominant pair and from several other birds relegated to another section of the pond; interval shortened at 1:18, 1:31, and 1:43, after the last a series of alarm calls (no idea why--I could not see them at this point) followed by some loud (best) interaction calls after 3:19; (all the thrashing in the reeds--perhaps grackles?); calling again after 4:07; interval shortened at 4:22, 4:36;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: at the start, the aggressor had another bird held under water for about 30 seconds while giving a loud alarm-type call, but it escaped, and there were several chases across the water as the aggressor (breeding plumage still, part of dominant pair) drove off a wintering bird on the pond (last audible water chase is American Coot after 0:30, followed by loud Coot calls through 0:55); last Grebe interaction is by three basic-plumaged birds (including the "loser") that got together with interaction calls after 2:43 (good) in one corner of the pond; interval shortened at 2:52 for more interaction calls;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: calls of begging juvenile, stripey bird about 2/3 adult size; a few calls (warning or summons) from adult, e.g., after 1:42;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.type: alarm call, begging call, call, pair interaction calls
recordings.rmk: breeding plumage adult; alarm calls or warning calls to a full-sized, striped juvenile that it was escorting a little away from danger (me) (even though it sees people everyday); a few calls from the juvenile (high-pitched); interval shortened at 2:09, after which the large juvenile is begging (it may be independent at this point, but still trying); interval shortened at 2:55 with excited adult calls in interaction not seen in the cattails with much thrashing around in the water, followed by some very soft calls by an adult;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: warning or alarm call from breeding adult, probably the male, to three full-sized, long-since out of the nest young (the adults have started another nest, but are still involved with the young); warning or alarm probably directed at me, although it is a large pond and they did not choose to swim farther from me; a few high, piping calls from the juveniles; same bird(s) as recorded on other visits; interval shortened at 2:09;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.type: alarm call, call, song, pair interaction calls
recordings.rmk: breeding pair, song duet and interactions, with four major ones at the start, 5:35, 7:34, and 8:51 (full duet), after which just a few calls like warm ups for songs that did not happen, e.g., after 10:00 and 10:33, with a few alarm calls after 12:06;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: breeding pair; song at start and at 3:00, pair calls at 4:57 in duet fashion, and pair interaction calls (brief) at 5:42;

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: a.p. adult, perhaps in response to me (at a marshy pond where they often breed); one loud alarm call then a few very soft notes;

recordings.loc: Parque metropolitano Simón Bolívar, Bogotá, Cundinamarca
recordings.rmk:
**Behavior:** Two medium-sized individuals (perhaps juveniles) were approaching with small beeps. Then one of them dove in and then emerged alongside the other starting a duet like the one on the recording.

**Weather:** 90% cloudy. Cold

**Recording distance:** 5 meters.

**Habitat:**  Lake

**Equipment:**

**Recorder:** TASCAM DR-40

**Microphone:** Audio-Technica AT875R

**Accessories:** Rycote 15cm Classic-Softie windshield, K-Tek KE89CC Boompole

recordings.loc: San Luis National Wildlife Refuge, Los Banos, Merced County, California
recordings.rmk:
This was first listed as a mystery. See the forum. The first, loudest, call note at 0:01.0 is usually heard as a series of calls. Listen to  XC305803. I'm pretty sure most of these Markdowns are also the Pied-billed Grebe.  Two calls starting at 2:15.5 and a third at 4:21.0? 

I was able to ID  these, at 0:02.0 and 6:07.02, as Pied-billed Grebes. Grebe at 2:50.5

And the two calls at the end starting at 7:23.0?

These were recorded in a fresh water wetland habitat.

Any help with the background species is also appreciated.

recordings.loc: El Tránsito, San Miguel
recordings.file-name: XC240545-Macho y hembra de Podilymbus podiceps llamando a pollos. Laguna El Jocotal El Salvador 09052014 Susana Vasquez.mp3
recordings.rmk: Área Natural Protegida Laguna El Jocotal. Grabación de video con cámara canon power shot SX50 HS. Se utilizo el programa Audacity 2.0.4 no se utilizo ningún efecto, finalmente se convirtió a mp3. Pareja de Podilymbus podiceps haciendo llamados de alerta a 3 pollos mientras se desplazaban en la laguna, siendo los llamados del macho mas fuertes y la hembra guardaba los pollos en su costado. Vegetación sumergida Hidrilla verticillata, vegetación flotante y emergente.

recordings.loc: Viera Wetlands, Florida
recordings.file-name: XC162113-Pied-billed Grebe saw a couple, at least one more hidden in marsh -FL, Viera, Dec 30, 2013, 1112 AM.mp3
recordings.rmk:
I heard some of the calls from the direction of a pair of Pied-billed Grebes, and some of the calls unseen from the marsh

I frequently hear this call from the marsh in the winter, but unseen; I first assumed it was a Sora call, but I hear it from the direction of Pied-billed Grebes when not hidden in marsh vegetation

I have since better witnessed Pied-billed Grebes making this call

recordings.loc: Walden Reservoir, Jackson Co., Colorado
recordings.rmk: Response to playback from a bird in cattail-lined pond. As it vocalized, its bill was slightly open, and the throat was inflated with each note, the head appeared laterally inflated a bit as well. Eventually, it swam into the cattails, continuing singing (this cut), where it could not be seen.

recordings.loc: Briones Res. Overlook, Orinda, Contra Costa County, California
recordings.rmk: Adult PBGR calling for about 5 minutes in the middle of Little John Cove. No other PBGRs observed. When the calling ended the bird dove and I didn't see or hear it again. Edited in Audacity with high pass filter. Recorded on iPhone with Lossless.
